Page.Name: Process Details
Page.Label: Repository Name
User Version No
Created By
Date Last Modified
Last Modified By
Date Created
Object Category
Page.Value: To solve a Major Incident. Major Incidents cause serious interruptions of business activities and must be solved with greater urgency. The aim is the fast recovery of the service, where necessary by means of a workaround. If required, specialist support groups or third-party suppliers (3rd Level Support) are involved. If the correction of the root cause is not possible, a Problem Record is created and the error-correction transfered to Problem Management.
Page.Label: Description
System Version No

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: A dynamically established team of IT managers and technical experts, usually under the leadership of the Incident Manager, formulated to concentrate on the resolution of a Major Incident.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: The Incident Manager is responsible for the effective implementation of the Incident Management process and carries out the corresponding reporting. He represents the first stage of escalation for Incidents, should these not be resolvable within the agreed Service Levels.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: The responsibility of 1st Level Support is to register and classify received Incidents and to undertake an immediate effort in order to restore a failed IT service as quickly as possible. If no ad-hoc solution can be achieved, 1st Level Support will transfer the Incident to expert technical support groups (2nd Level Support). 1st Level Support also keeps users informed about their Incidents' status at agreed intervals.
Prop.Label: Description

Shape.Name: Annotation.258
Shape.Text: identify a solution, either for eliminating the Incident's root cause or for reinstating the service by means of a workaround; also check if existing recovery plans may be invoked

Shape.Name: Annotation.277
Shape.Text: urgent RFCs and the corresponding Emergency Changes are handled by the Change Management process using a specific procedure

Shape.Name: Annotation.251
Shape.Text: determine which IT managers and technical experts must be informed and are needed in order to swiftly resolve the Major Incident

Shape.Name: Annotation.284
Shape.Text: Assessment and authorization of the urgent Change by the Emergency Change Advisory Board (ECAB)

Shape.Name: Annotation.274
Shape.Text: create a Problem Record in order to ensure that the Incident's root cause will subsequently be resolved by Problem Management

Shape.Name: Annotation.260
Shape.Text: in cases where cooperation with the business side is needed to solve the Incident

Shape.Name: Annotation.289
Shape.Text: apply tests or check with the user to ensure that the failed service is actually restored

Shape.Name: Sheet.13
Shape.Text: (Standby-Agreements must be in place for emergencies)

Shape.Name: Annotation.269
Shape.Text: Root cause for Incident can be resolved

Shape.Name: Annotation.270
Shape.Text: Incident can be resolved by Workaround

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: A set of data with all details of an Incident, documenting the history of the Incident from registration to resolution. An Incident is defined as an unplanned interruption or reduction in quality of an IT service. Every event that could potentially impair an IT service in the future is also an Incident (e.g. the failure of one hard-drive of a set of mirrored drives).
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: The Problem Record contains all details of a Problem, documenting the history of the Problem from detection to resolution.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: The Configuration Management System (CMS) is a coherent logical model of the IT organization’s infrastructure, typically made up of several Configuration Management Databases (CMDBs) as physical sub-systems. It is used to store information on all Configuration Items (CIs) under the control of Configuration Management.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: A formal request for a Change to be implemented. An RFC includes details of the proposed Change, and may be recorded on paper or electronically. The term RFC is often misused to mean a Change Record, or the Change in itself.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: Recovery Plans are created mainly by Availability and IT Service Continuity Management. The plans contain detailed instructions for returning services to a working state.
Prop.Label: Description

Shape.Name: Task.549
Shape.Text: If required, inform business side and align efforts

Prop.Name: sys_RepositoryName
Prop.Value: If required, inform business side and align efforts
Prop.Label: Repository Name

Shape.Name: Task.605
Shape.Text: Decide on resources needed to resolve the Incident

Prop.Name: sys_RepositoryName
Prop.Value: Decide on resources needed to resolve the Incident
Prop.Label: Repository Name

Shape.Name: Task.633
Shape.Text: Create a Problem Record linked to the Incident

Prop.Name: sys_RepositoryName
Prop.Value: Create a Problem Record linked to the Incident
Prop.Label: Repository Name

Shape.Name: Task.661
Shape.Text: If necessary, submit urgent RFC to Change Management

Prop.Name: sys_RepositoryName
Prop.Value: If necessary, submit urgent RFC to Change Management
Prop.Label: Repository Name

Shape.Name: Task.717
Shape.Text: Verify that the Incident resolution is complete

Prop.Name: sys_RepositoryName
Prop.Value: Verify that the Incident resolution is complete
Prop.Label: Repository Name

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To build and deploy IT services. This process also makes sure that changes to services and Service Management processes are carried out in a coordinated way.
Prop.Label: Description

Shape.Name: Sheet.415
Shape.Text: Process Objective: To solve a Major Incident. Major Incidents cause serious interruptions of business activities and must be solved with greater urgency. The aim is the fast recovery of the service, where necessary by means of a workaround. If required, specialist support groups or third-party suppliers (3rd Level Support) are involved. If the correction of the root cause is not possible, a Problem Record is created and the error-correction transfered to Problem Management.

Prop.Name: Note
Prop.Value: A problem that has a documented root cause and a workaround. Known Errors are created and managed throughout their lifecycle by Problem Management. Known Errors may also be identified by development or suppliers.
Prop.Label: Note

Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: Note
Prop.Value: Reducing or eliminating the impact of an Incident or Problem for which a full resolution is not yet available, for example by restarting a failed Configuration Item. Workarounds for Problems are documented in Known Error records.
Prop.Label: Note

Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: Note
Prop.Value: The Service Transition Report is an overall summary of all planned or ongoing Service Transition projects for deploying major Releases, listing key project data like milestones and current project status.
Prop.Label: Note

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: The Service Transition Report is an overall summary of all planned or ongoing Service Transition projects for deploying major Releases, listing key project data like milestones and current project status.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: Note
Prop.Value: The Projected Service Outage (PSO) document lists any expected deviations from the service availability agreed in SLAs.
Prop.Label: Note

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: The Projected Service Outage (PSO) document lists any expected deviations from the service availability agreed in SLAs.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: Note
Prop.Value: A warning produced by IT Security Management, typically released when outbreaks of security threats are foreseeable or already under way. The aim is to make sure that users and IT staff are able to identify any attacks and take appropriate precautions.
Prop.Label: Note

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: A warning produced by IT Security Management, typically released when outbreaks of security threats are foreseeable or already under way. The aim is to make sure that users and IT staff are able to identify any attacks and take appropriate precautions.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: Note
Prop.Value: A request to support the resolution of an Incident or Problem, usually issued from the Incident or Problem Management processes when further assistance is needed from technical experts.
Prop.Label: Note

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: A request to support the resolution of an Incident or Problem, usually issued from the Incident or Problem Management processes when further assistance is needed from technical experts.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: Note
Prop.Value: A list of known security vulnerabilities compiled from input by third-party product suppliers. The list contains instructions for preventive measures and for the handling of security breaches once they occur.
Prop.Label: Note

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: A list of known security vulnerabilities compiled from input by third-party product suppliers. The list contains instructions for preventive measures and for the handling of security breaches once they occur.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Label: AssignedTo

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: Recovery Plans are created mainly by Availability and IT Service Continuity Management. The plans contain detailed instructions for returning services to a working state.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: Note
Prop.Value: A catalogue of all information that is relevant in the event of disasters. This document is maintained and circulated by IT Service Continuity Management to all members of IT staff with responsibilities for fighting disasters.
Prop.Label: Note

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: A catalogue of all information that is relevant in the event of disasters. This document is maintained and circulated by IT Service Continuity Management to all members of IT staff with responsibilities for fighting disasters.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To record and prioritize the Incident with appropriate diligence, in order to facilitate a swift and effective resolution.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To manage the lifecycle of all Problems. The primary objectives of Problem Management are to prevent Incidents from happening, and to minimize the impact of incidents that cannot be prevented. Proactive Problem Management analyzes Incident Records, and uses data collected by other IT Service Management processes to identify trends or significant Problems.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To build and deploy IT services. This process also makes sure that changes to services and Service Management processes are carried out in a coordinated way.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To design new IT services. Its scope includes the design of new services, as well as changes and improvements to existing ones.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To solve a Major Incident. Major Incidents cause serious interruptions of business activities and must be solved with greater urgency. The aim is the fast recovery of the service, where necessary by means of a workaround. If required, specialist support groups or third-party suppliers (3rd Level Support) are involved. If the correction of the root cause is not possible, a Problem Record is created and the error-correction transfered to Problem Management.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To assess the course of the Change implementation and the achieved results, in order to verify that a complete history if activities is present for future reference, and to make sure that any mistakes are analyzed and lessons learned.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To submit the Incident Record to a final quality control before it is closed. The aim is to make sure that the Incident is actually resolved and that all information required to describe the Incident's life-cycle is supplied in sufficient detail. In addition to this, findings from the resolution of the Incident are to be recorded for future use.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To manage the lifecycle of all Problems. The primary objectives of Problem Management are to prevent Incidents from happening, and to minimize the impact of incidents that cannot be prevented. Proactive Problem Management analyzes Incident Records, and uses data collected by other IT Service Management processes to identify trends or significant Problems.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To build and deploy IT services. This process also makes sure that changes to services and Service Management processes are carried out in a coordinated way.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To monitor and control the IT services and infrastructure. The process IT Operations Management executes day-to-day routine tasks related to the operation of infrastructure components and applications. This includes job scheduling, backup and restore activities, print and output management, and routine maintenance.
Prop.Label: Description

Prop.Name: sys_Description
Prop.Value: To manage the physical environment where the IT infrastructure is located. Facilities Management includes all aspects of managing the physical environment, for example power and cooling, building access management, and environmental monitoring.
Prop.Label: Description
